nodes.text: Conditional convergence hypothesis: cross-country per capita GDP growth (1960-1985) is positively related to initial human capital and negatively related to initial per capita GDP when human capital is held constant
Initial human capital (proxied by 1960 school-enrollment rates at primary and secondary levels) is positively associated with subsequent per capita GDP growth
Holding initial human capital constant, higher initial real per capita GDP (1960) is negatively associated with subsequent per capita GDP growth (1960-1985)
Higher initial human capital is associated with lower fertility (net surviving children) and higher physical-investment-to-GDP ratios
Higher government consumption share of GDP is negatively related to per capita growth and to private investment; public investment shows little positive association with growth
Political instability (revolutions, coups, political assassinations) is negatively related to investment and to growth
Market price distortions, proxied by deviations in purchasing-power-parity for investment deflators, are negatively associated with growth and investment

The weak growth performance of sub-Saharan Africa and Latin America is not fully explained by included variables (human capital, investment, fertility, government consumption, instability, price distortions)

Method: cross-sectional OLS regressions for a sample of 98 countries (mostly 1960-1985), using school-enrollment rates as human-capital proxies; standard errors adjusted with White heteroskedasticity-consistent covariance matrix; some regressions weighted by GDP or population

Assumption and proxy choice: school-enrollment rates (1960) proxy initial stock of human capital though they partly measure flow; supplementary proxies include 1950 enrollment, student-teacher ratios, and adult literacy

Evidence (regression 1): coefficient on GDP60 is -0.0075 (s.e. 0.0012) meaning an extra $1,000 initial GDP per capita lowers annual growth by 0.75 percentage point when human-capital and other controls held fixed; partial correlation between growth residual and GDP60 is -0.74

Evidence (regression 1): coefficients on SEC60 and PRIM60 are positive and significant (approx. 0.0305 and 0.0250); partial correlation of growth with human-capital proxy is 0.73, implying human-capital range 'explains' roughly five percentage points in growth rate variation

Evidence for fertility: regressions show FERTNET is strongly negatively correlated with school-enrollment variables and weakly related to GDP60; gross fertility relates to child mortality but net fertility (surviving children) is explained by human-capital measures

Evidence on causality and measurement: adding 1950 enrollment rates and 1970 rates suggests 1960 primary enrollment proxies initial human-capital stock rather than only flow; student-teacher ratio for primary 1960 negatively related to growth, supporting human-capital interpretation

Evidence on investment links: private and total investment ratios are positively correlated with human-capital proxies and negatively (partially) with GDP60; residuals of growth and investment equations are positively correlated (consistent with endogenous-growth models)

Conclusion: Results support conditional convergence—poor countries with higher-than-typical human capital tend to grow faster—but many factors remain unexplained, notably adverse continent effects for sub-Saharan Africa and Latin America

Evidence on government spending: gc/y (government consumption excluding education and defense) has a negative coefficient on growth (~ -0.12) and on private investment; public investment ratio shows little robust positive effect on growth when total investment is included
Evidence on political instability: REV and ASSASS coefficients are significantly negative for growth and for private investment, consistent with adverse effects on property rights and investment

Evidence on price distortions: magnitude of deviation in PPP for investment deflator (PPIGODEV) negatively associated with growth (coefficient ~ -0.014) and with investment ratios; sign of deviation less important than magnitude
